issues.description: The problem statement states that printf here expects two arguments (format first, then the string) (problem_statement.md line 16), but the template calls printf with only one pushed argument (template_repository/helloWorld.asm lines 15-16: 'push hello' then 'call printf'). This mismatch can confuse students about the correct calling convention to use and may lead to runtime/formatting errors. The template should either push a format string before calling printf (and declare that format in the .data section) or the problem statement should clarify that the provided call intentionally uses the string as the format.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the template and the problem statement agree on printf usage. Preferred fix: add a format string in .data (e.g. fmt db "%s", 10, 0) and change the call sequence to push the string then push the format before calling printf (push hello; push fmt; call printf). Alternatively, if the intent was to use the string itself as the format, update the problem statement to state that only one argument is used in this template.

issues.description: The solution uses a different entry point and a different program structure than the template and the problem description. The template declares 'global main' and uses extern printf and a .data section (template_repository/helloWorld.asm lines 6-8 and 2-3), while the solution declares 'global CMAIN' and contains no data or printf usage (solution_repository/helloWorld.asm lines 4-6 and 16-18). This discrepancy may confuse students when they compare their modified template to the provided solution (they may look for a 'main' label or printf usage that the solution does not show).
issues.suggested_fix: Align the solution with the template/problem statement or explicitly document the intended differences. Preferred fix: provide a solution variant that uses the same entry label ('main'), includes the same .data section and extern printf, and demonstrates the corrected instruction (add eax, ecx). If the solution intentionally uses a different entry point (CMAIN) or omits printf for simplification, add a note in the problem statement explaining this to avoid confusion.
